perturbation.original_text: If you do not make the extra payment within 60 days from the date we notify you of your share of the deficiency, the amount will be charged as an indebtedness against the contract with interest compounded at the rate of 5% per year.
perturbation.changed_text: If you do not make the extra payment within 10 days from the date we notify you of your share of the deficiency, the amount will be charged as an indebtedness against the contract with interest compounded at the rate of 5% per year.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the payment period for deficiency payments to 10 days may not provide sufficient time for individuals to respond, especially considering potential delays in mail or other communication methods. This contradicts the general principle of providing reasonable notice and opportunity to cure deficiencies.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Wisconsin Statutes section 705.08(1) (Right to Cure a Default)
perturbation.law_explanation: Although this statute speaks directly to transfers of property, similar concepts of sufficient time to cure defaults apply to insurance contracts to ensure fairness and prevent unjust enrichment. Providing only 10 days to respond to deficiency notice contradicts the spirit of allowing reasonable time to cure the issue.

perturbation.original_text: Each year, we will determine our divisible surplus. This contract's share, if any, will be credited as a dividend. Since we do not expect this contract to contribute to divisible surplus, it is not expected that any dividends will be credited.
perturbation.changed_text: We will determine our divisible surplus at our sole discretion, and this contract's share, if any, will be determined at our sole discretion. We reserve the right to never credit any dividends.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the wording to allow 'sole discretion' and reserve the right to never credit dividends creates uncertainty and potential conflict with state laws regarding fair practices for insurance contracts, especially if the contract implies dividends might be paid.
perturbation.law_explanation: This statute prohibits unfair discrimination between individuals of the same class in insurance rates, policy fees, benefits, or other policy terms.  The modified text allows for arbitrary dividend determinations that could violate this statute if applied in a discriminatory manner.

perturbation.original_text: Dividends are applied as payment of a Net Premium.
perturbation.changed_text: Dividends will not be applied as payment of Net Premium. All dividends, if any, will be forfeited to the insurer.
perturbation.explanation: Forcing forfeiture of dividends directly contradicts policyholder rights and could violate regulations against unfair insurance practices if the policy implies dividends can be used in a certain way.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Wisconsin Statutes section 628.34(1) (Form and content of insurance policies)
perturbation.law_explanation: This statute requires insurance policies to be readable and understandable.  Changing the dividend application to forfeiture without clear, conspicuous, and unequivocal notice could be considered misleading and violate the statute's intent, as it goes against the implied benefit of receiving dividends.
